value: A few of Ikata's many mountaintop windmills.

.  It spans the mountainous Sadamisaki Peninsula, the narrowest peninsula in Japan.  Ikata's breath-taking combination of mountain and ocean scenery makes it a wonderful place for a leisurely afternoon drive.
The best way to get to Ikata is by car.  Bring your own, or rent one in

value: Take the oceanside scenic route:  Take Route 378 south from Matsuyama along the beautiful Futami and
coastline.  Take a right at the junction with Route 197.
Take the misty mountain freeway route:  Take the Matsuyama Expressway south past
, then get off and take Route 197 through Yawatahama and the rest of the way to Ikata.

You can also get close to Ikata by train—just take an express on the JR Yosan line from Matsuyama to Yawatahama.  From there you can hop a bus or take a taxi, but beware that taxis get quite pricey.
, you can also catch a ferry from either
, to Misaki Port at Ikata's tip.
Buses run the length of the peninsula, but car is still the number one way to go.

value: content=This lighthouse stands at the tip of the peninsula, overlooking the Hōyo Strait.  On clear days you can see across to Kyūshū.  1.8 km of hiking trails and a campground lay at its feet.

content=This park is located atop a mountain in the Seto area.  From it you can see many of Ikata's numerous windmills, spinning above the Inland Sea to the north and the Pacific Ocean to the south.  Haikus about the windmills, submitted for Ikata's Windmill Festival, are on display in the park.  See
from the park, updated every hour.

content=This hands-on science museum teaches all about nuclear power with beautiful interactive displays and fun activities for all ages.  The building is connected to the Kirara-kan, which houses an aquarium and sells souvenirs and local agricultural products.
content=Named after Ikata's sister city, this park is home to Adventure Hill—a playground full of climbing nets, roller slides, and other exciting children's play equipment.

content=A new hot spring bathing facility and park are currently under construction and will be open to the public in July 2007.  According to legend, a giant crab lives in the adjacent Kamegaike Pond.

Ikata has two Roadside Stations where you can buy locally-made goods.  Ikata's mikan juice can't be beat!
These restaurants are conveniently located right along Route 197.
